metadata.title: A Julia set model of field-directed morphogenesis: developmental biology and artificial life
metadata.abstract: One paradigm in understanding the control of morphogenetic events is the concept of positional information, where spatial cues are used to determine cell fate.  A major problem is to determine what kinds of positional characteristics may be obtained by what methods, and what the characteristics of such a morphogenetic process might be. In this paper a model is presented of positional information. In this model, the interactions of mutually based on gene activity driven by complex number algebra. Interactions resulting in position-dependent differentiation. This is seen in sufficient complex variables are used to simulate genetic functions to resulting to produce a very rich set of morphologies which are similar in appearance and morphologies; as positional information is guiding factors in several important developmental processes. Therefore, the implications of this model can be used to study potential role of fields and process. It is shown that the gene interactions can be modeled as a multi-dimensional algebra, and that only two interacting functions. The model simultaneously displays the positional information for the study of static images, time-series to elucidate the positional information. This model is meant to charecterize behavior, and fill the field of positional information, which is a valuable method for obtaining quantitative data are not currently available on the interplay of the various organism's development. Good simulation of images produced with actual pictures of any particular real organism. A brief introduction to formal morphologies to biological development are discussed, in terms of theoretical background and perspectives of the various models and positional information are followed by the top-down of shape, parameterization studies, time series, movie, static experimental perturbation. All figures (in grayscale)

chunks.text: CABIOS FIRST BYTE
chunks.section: CABIOS FIRST BYTE
chunks.chunk_summary: This section mentions the journal CABIOS and the term 'FIRST BYTE'.

chunks.section: Vol
chunks.chunk_summary: This section provides the volume, issue number, and year of the publication.

chunks.text: Pages 85-103
chunks.section: Pages
chunks.chunk_summary: The provided section indicates the article spans from page 85 to 103.

chunks.text: A Julia set model of field-directed morphogenesis is explored, bridging developmental biology and artificial life. This approach uses the mathematical framework of Julia sets to model how biological fields can guide the development of shape and form in organisms.  By applying principles from artificial life, this model seeks to understand the complex dynamics of morphogenesis and how biological systems achieve robust and reproducible patterns during development.
chunks.section: A J
chunks.chunk_summary: A Julia set model is used to explore field-directed morphogenesis, connecting developmental biology and artificial life to understand how biological fields influence shape development.

chunks.text: Michael Levin is a biologist known for his work on bioelectricity and its role in development, regeneration, and cancer. His research explores how cells communicate electrically to coordinate complex morphogenetic processes. Levin's work has significant implications for regenerative medicine, synthetic biology, and the understanding of fundamental biological processes.
chunks.section: Michael Levin
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk introduces Michael Levin and his research focus on bioelectricity and its role in biological processes like development, regeneration, and cancer.

chunks.text: Abstract
chunks.section: Abstract
chunks.chunk_summary: This section is the abstract of the paper.

chunks.text: One paradigm used in understanding the control of morphogenetic events is the concept of positional information, where sub-organismic components (such as cells) act in response to positional cues. It is important to determine what kinds of spatiotemporal patterns may be obtained by such a method, and what the characteristics of such a morphogenetic process might be. This paper presents a computer model of morphogenesis based on gene activity driven by interpreting a positional information field. In this model, the interactions of mutually regulating developmental genes are viewed as a map from R² to R², and are modeled by the complex number algebra. Functions in complex variables are used to simulate genetic interactions resulting in position-dependent differentiation. This is shown to be equivalent to computing modified Julia sets, and is seen to be sufficient to produce a very rich set of morphologies which are similar in appearance and several important characteristics to those of real organisms.
chunks.section: One paradigm used in understanding the control of morphogenetic events is the concept of positional information
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk introduces the concept of positional information in morphogenesis and describes a computer model using complex number algebra to simulate gene interactions and resulting morphologies.

chunks.text: The properties of this model can be used to study the potential role of fields and positional information as guiding factors in morphogenesis, as the model facilitates the study of static images, time-series (movies) and experimental alterations of the developmental process. It is thus shown that gene interactions can be modeled as a multi-dimensional algebra, and that only two interacting genes are sufficient for (i) complex pattern formation, (ii) chaotic differentiation behavior, and (iii) production of sharp edges from a continuous positional information field. This model is meant to elucidate the properties of the process of positional information-guided biomorphogenesis, not to serve as a simulation of any particular organism's development.
chunks.section: One paradigm used in understanding the control of morphogenetic events is the concept of positional information
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk highlights the model's capabilities for studying positional information's role in morphogenesis, including pattern formation and chaotic differentiation, emphasizing its general applicability rather than organism-specific simulation.

chunks.text: Good quantitative data are not currently available on the interplay of gene products in morphogenesis. Thus, no attempt is made to link the images produced with actual pictures of any particular real organism. A brief introduction to top-down models and positional information is followed by the formal definition of the model. Then, the implications of the resulting morphologies to biological development are discussed, in terms of static shapes, parametrization studies, time series (movies made from individual frames), and behavior of the model in light of experimental perturbations. All figures (in grayscale), formulas and parameter values needed to re-create the figures and movies are included.
chunks.section: One paradigm used in understanding the control of morphogenetic events is the concept of positional information
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk acknowledges the lack of quantitative data for organism-specific validation, outlines the paper's structure, including model definition and analysis of resulting morphologies, and mentions the inclusion of figures and parameters for reproducibility.

chunks.text: Introduction[PAGE 85]
chunks.section: [PAGE 85] Introduction
chunks.chunk_summary: This section serves as a brief introduction.

chunks.text: The biology of artificial life.
chunks.section: The biology of artificial life
chunks.chunk_summary: This section introduces the concept of the biology of artificial life.

chunks.text: Computer models can serve as biological theories (as in Garfinkel, 1984; Partridge and Lopez, 1984). The rapidly growing field of artificial life uses computer models to emphasize the common processes and characteristics of living things, rather than their physico-chemical implementation.
chunks.section: Computer models can serve as biological theories
chunks.chunk_summary: Computer models can function as biological theories, with artificial life emphasizing common life processes over specific implementations.

chunks.text: The accent is on the role of bioinformation, cybernetic control processes, complexity and systems theory, rather than the study of specific instances of physicochemical processes (Apter, 1966: Goel and Thompson, 1986; Langton, 1990, 1991).
chunks.section: Computer models can serve as biological theories
chunks.chunk_summary: The focus is on bioinformation, cybernetic control, complexity, and systems theory, rather than specific physicochemical instances.

chunks.text: Computer simulations provide the experimental biologist with a much needed means for doing experiments on theories. We usually think of experiments as something performed on cells, to determine whether the cells' responses will match predictions made by a theory. However, when dealing with complex phenomena and with correspondingly complex theories, what a given hypothesis predicts can be less than obvious.
chunks.section: Computer simulations provide the experimental biologist with a much needed means for doing experiments on theories
chunks.chunk_summary: Computer simulations offer a valuable tool for testing complex biological theories, especially when predictions are not readily apparent from the theory itself.

chunks.text: It can be even more difficult to perceive which components in the hypothesis give rise to a particular prediction, much less to know what alternative classes of hypothesis would have predicted the same results. Lastly, anyone with sufficient insight to predict the consequences of a given theory may need objective methods for providing it to others. Computer simulations can help solve all these problems. (Harris, 1990)
chunks.section: Computer simulations provide the experimental biologist with a much needed means for doing experiments on theories
chunks.chunk_summary: Simulations aid in identifying the components of a hypothesis responsible for specific predictions, exploring alternative hypotheses, and objectively communicating theoretical consequences.

chunks.text: This approach sits at the intersection of biology, mathematics, physics, and computer science, primarily focusing on computer models of behavior or evolution.  Researchers have attempted to model developmental phenomena like cell proliferation, cleavage, migration, and pattern formation through computer simulations of underlying components.
chunks.section: This approach is at the intersection of biology
chunks.chunk_summary: This approach uses computational models to simulate and understand developmental phenomena.

chunks.text: Several studies have explored this computational approach.  Ransom (1981) and Meinhardt (1982) provide comprehensive summaries of these early efforts.  Other notable examples include the work of Düchting and Vogelsaenger (1984, 1985) and Thom (1983).  The 'bottom-up' model, where emergent phenomena arise from simulations of lower-level component behaviors, is exemplified by Goel and Roger (1978) and Rogers and Goel (1978).
chunks.section: This approach is at the intersection of biology
chunks.chunk_summary: The chunk summarizes key prior research in computational modeling of developmental processes, highlighting the 'bottom-up' approach.

chunks.text: In the 'top-down' model (sometimes termed 'informal'- Conrad, 1981), the researcher creates a computer simulation which behaves like the system modeled (in some interesting way), without too much regard for the empirical validity of specific lower-level components; the model's empirical fitness is tested at a higher level. This approach can be used to study characteristics of processes or general schemes. For example, one may create a well-fitting model of some animal's social behavior based on general principles of co-operation, game theory and information theory, without any regard as to whether the components of the equations have any physical counterparts in the animal's brain (e.g. Krebs et al., 1978; Axelrod and Hamilton, 1981).
chunks.section: In the
chunks.chunk_summary: Top-down models prioritize high-level behavior over the precise biological implementation of lower-level components, focusing on overall system behavior and often preceding bottom-up approaches.

chunks.text: These kinds of models usually precede bottom-up models, and are much more common in ethology, evolutionary theory and the cognitive sciences than in developmental biology. Excellent examples of top-down models are given in Raup and Michelson (1965), Rozenberg and Salomaa (1986) and Slack (1991). L-systems (Lindenmeyer, 1989; Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmeyer, 1990) are among the best examples of top-down models because they possess the appropriate higher-order behavior even though there is no known physical mechanism in plants which explicitly implements the symbol manipulation rules used in an L-system.
chunks.section: In the
chunks.chunk_summary: Top-down models are prevalent in fields like ethology and cognitive science, with L-systems serving as a prime example due to their ability to capture complex behavior without direct biological correspondence.

chunks.text: Whereas the bottom-up model tries to be as realistic and focused as possible, providing empirically accurate data of some narrow and specific aspect of development (e.g. Meinhardt, 1984; Ransom, 1984), the top-down model attempts to derive the overall pattern of control, information flow and higher-order characteristics at the cost of losing some lower-level realism. Bottom-up models are able to provide more concrete information about some narrowly defined process; the benefit of the top-down model is that it allows insight into the higher-order properties of processes, and can be used when sufficient data and/or theory for a bottom-up model is not available.
chunks.section: Whereas the bottom
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk contrasts bottom-up and top-down modeling approaches in developmental biology, highlighting their respective strengths and weaknesses in capturing different levels of detail and overall control mechanisms.

chunks.text: These models are useful in the study of developmental morphogenesis because embryonic development is very likely to involve general mechanisms of increasing complexity; at the same time, much low-level data (such as quantitative mechanisms of gene interactions) are currently unavailable. This paper presents a positional field-driven model of development which is intermediate between the bottom-up and top-down types.
chunks.section: Whereas the bottom
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk emphasizes the utility of different modeling approaches in studying developmental morphogenesis, noting the current lack of detailed low-level data and introducing the paper's proposed positional field-driven model as an intermediate approach.

chunks.text: Positional information and field concepts are used in biology to understand how cells organize and develop into complex structures. Cellular automata systems, as described by Gutowitz (1991), provide a clear example of these concepts. These systems model how local interactions between cells, based on their relative positions and the influence of surrounding fields, can give rise to emergent patterns and behaviors at a larger scale.
chunks.section: [PAGE 86] Positional information and field concepts in biology (best exemplified by cellular automata systems, as in Gutowitz, 1991).
chunks.chunk_summary: Positional information and field concepts, exemplified by cellular automata systems, explain how local cell interactions create large-scale patterns in biological development.

chunks.text: The basic problem of pattern formation can be viewed from one (or a combination) of two general perspectives. The developing organism's resulting morphology can be seen as a product of subunits following a sort of master plan - a blueprint (at some level of detail) of the whole organism.
chunks.section: The basic problem of pattern formation can be viewed from one
chunks.chunk_summary: One perspective on pattern formation views morphology as arising from a pre-determined blueprint guiding subunit organization.

chunks.text: Or, it may be an emergent phenomenon, where the overall pattern emerges as the result of purely local interactions between subunits governed by rules which say nothing about the overall pattern.
chunks.section: The basic problem of pattern formation can be viewed from one
chunks.chunk_summary: Alternatively, pattern formation can be seen as an emergent property arising from local interactions between subunits, without a global plan.

chunks.text: An intermediate paradigm involves positional information (Wolpert, 1969, 1971, 1989). That is, each unit (usually thought of as a cell, but this could apply equally well to tissues, cell sheets or subcellular components) is able to determine its position within the organism, and act (differentiate, migrate, proliferate, etc.) based upon that positional information. The positional information is usually thought of as coordinates in a field, which then can be a mechanism for long-range control and information transfer (see Cooke, 1975, for a review of field theories in biology). The paradigm is thus a combination of the two approaches in that it includes both purely local decision-making (with an emphasis on the distinction between the field itself, and various components' responses to it), as well as a global entity (the positional information field itself).
chunks.section: An intermediate paradigm involves positional information
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk introduces the concept of positional information as a paradigm for understanding morphogenesis, where units within an organism determine their actions based on their position within a field.

chunks.text: In this view, the overall morphology emerges from units following rules which specify actions based on the unit's position; the process of morphogenesis can be 'characterized as a series of solutions of the morphogenetic field whose superposition gives way to complex stable patterns' (Goodwin, 1988). The role of positional information in early development is reviewed in Bard (1990) and Slack (1991); there is also evidence that adult animals maintain positional information cues (Harrison, 1918; Raff and Kauffman, 1983).
chunks.section: An intermediate paradigm involves positional information
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk explains how morphology arises from units acting based on their position within the morphogenetic field, and highlights the role of positional information in both early development and adult organisms.

chunks.text: The field is a very attractive theoretical construct for modeling global influences and thus explaining static stability as well as temporal change of a complex morphology, and the ability of numerous processes to combine into a coherent whole and to tend toward that configuration when experimentally perturbed (Goodwin, 1985).
chunks.section: The field is a very attractive theoretical construct for modeling global influences and thus explaining static stability as well as temporal change of a complex morphology
chunks.chunk_summary: A theoretical construct, referred to as "the field," is proposed as a model for understanding global influences on morphology, explaining both its stability and dynamic changes.

chunks.text: In real organisms, there must at critical times or even continuously be an overlay of global instructions that keeps the ramifying network of inductive interactions in the correct relationship by specifying reference to whole-organism properties. (Thomson, 1988)
chunks.section: The field is a very attractive theoretical construct for modeling global influences and thus explaining static stability as well as temporal change of a complex morphology
chunks.chunk_summary: Global instructions are necessary in organisms to maintain the correct relationships within the network of inductive interactions, referencing whole-organism properties.

chunks.text: Fields have recently become truly useful in the study of development through mathematical models (see, for example, French et al., 1966; Goodwin and Cohen, 1969; Goodwin and Trainor, 1980; Ransom, 1981; Trainor, 1982; Goodwin and LaCroix, 1984; Goodwin et al., 1987; Nagorcka, 1989; Brandts and Trainor, 1990a,b) and empirical confirmation of their existence and crucial role in development (Burr, 1941; Lund, 1947; Cooke, 1972a-c, 1973a-c; Jaffe, 1979; Kropf and Caldwell 1983; Nucitelli, 1986; Gow, 1987).
chunks.section: Fields have recently become truly useful in the study of development through mathematical models
chunks.chunk_summary: Mathematical models and empirical evidence support the existence and importance of fields in developmental biology.

chunks.text: Field theories are useful in explaining the phenomena of cleavage (e.g. Goodwin and Trainor, 1980), regeneration (e.g. Tevlin and Trainor, 1985; Mittenthal and Nuelle, 1988), supernumerary limb production (e.g. Bryant and Iten, 1976; Mittenthal and Trevarrow, 1984; Gardiner and Bryant, 1989), and cancer and malignancy (Matioli, 1987).
chunks.section: Fields have recently become truly useful in the study of development through mathematical models
chunks.chunk_summary: Field theories provide explanations for various developmental phenomena, including cleavage, regeneration, supernumerary limb production, and cancer.

chunks.text: Julia set models can be used to represent field-driven development.  These models, based on fractal geometry, capture the iterative and self-similar patterns often observed in biological growth and form.  While simplified, they offer a computational framework for exploring how global field properties can influence local cell behaviors and ultimately shape complex morphologies.  This approach allows for the investigation of how variations in field parameters can lead to diverse developmental outcomes, providing a theoretical bridge between bioelectric patterns and anatomical structure.
chunks.section: [PAGE 87] Julia set model of field-driven development
chunks.chunk_summary: Julia set models, based on fractal geometry, provide a computational framework for understanding how global field properties influence local cell behaviors and shape complex morphologies in development.

chunks.text: Two interesting top-down field-based models are given by Evans (1986) and Thompson (1961). Evans' model involves generation of morphologies very similar to that of the human fetus, based on electromagnetic field characteristics of the nervous system.
chunks.section: Two interesting top
chunks.chunk_summary: Evans' model generates morphologies similar to a human fetus based on nervous system electromagnetic fields.

chunks.text: Thompson (1961) and Palmer (1957) show that it is possible to convert between the morphologies of various existing animals by applying simple mathematical deformations to their two-dimensional field representations. Field theories must specify several characteristics of the process: the physical nature of the field; what exactly perceives this information; what the time characteristics of field perception are; and how the field is in turn modified by the units that read it.
chunks.section: Two interesting top
chunks.chunk_summary: Thompson and Palmer demonstrate morphological transformations through mathematical deformations of field representations, highlighting the need for field theories to specify field characteristics, perception mechanisms, and feedback loops.

chunks.text: A field can consist of a chemical morphogen gradient or system of gradients (e.g. Russel, 1985; French, 1988; Green et al., 1992), an electromagnetic field (patterns of ionic currents and potential differences, e.g. Nucitelli, 1984, 1986), an osmotic field (O'Shea, 1988), a field of differential adhesiveness (haptotactic fields, as in Murray and Oster, 1984; Zackson and Steinberg, 1988; Lord and Sanders, 1992) or a visco-elastic tension field (e.g. Lakirev and Belousov, 1986; Hart et al., 1989; Brière and Goodwin, 1990).
chunks.section: A
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk lists various types of physical fields that can influence morphogenesis, including chemical, electromagnetic, osmotic, adhesive, and tension fields.

chunks.text: The salient point is that there is some physical factor which forms a field throughout the embryo (though it is not necessarily the case that every part of the embryo utilizes the information in it), such that units (cells, for example) can interact with it and thus obtain information about their position within the embryo. The model described in this paper is not committed to any specific physical nature of the field; it applies to all Cartesian fields.
chunks.section: A
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk emphasizes the importance of physical fields in providing positional information to cells within the embryo, allowing them to understand their location and contribute to overall development, with the proposed model being applicable to any Cartesian field.

chunks.text: The basic unit capable of interpreting positional information fields, referred to as "field reading," can vary in scale. It doesn't necessarily have to be individual cells; it could be a subcellular component (Frankel, 1974), a group of cells, or even a sheet of cells (Hart and Trainor, 1989).  Research has also explored the temporal aspects of field reading. For example, Savel'ev (1988) demonstrated that neuroepithelial cells in amphibian brains read their positional information, which in this case is stored as a mechanical strain field, at specific time intervals. These cells exhibit time-limited field perception events, suggesting discrete moments of information processing. This model also assumes that field interpretation occurs in distinct steps.
chunks.section: The basic unit of field
chunks.chunk_summary: Field reading, the interpretation of positional information, can occur at various scales, from subcellular components to cell sheets, and involves discrete temporal events.

chunks.text: The dynamic interplay between the sources generating positional information fields and the fields themselves is a crucial area of study. However, to simplify the model presented in this paper, the focus will be on a pre-existing static field and how receivers interact with the information it contains. This simplification allows for a more focused analysis of field interpretation mechanisms without the added complexity of dynamic field changes.
chunks.section: The basic unit of field
chunks.chunk_summary: While the dynamics of field generation and interaction are important, this model simplifies the analysis by focusing on a static field and receiver interaction.

chunks.text: Many attempts to model specific developmental processes exist (see Ransom, 1981; Meinhardt, 1982, for reviews). Some are based on continuous functions and differential equations (such as Yates and Pate, 1989), while others are based on finite-state automata and discrete finite-mathematical methods (e.g. Herman and Rozenberg, 1975; MacDonald, 1983). Although the field concept has been useful in various specific applications, it is an open question as to whether positional information in general can account for the morphological complexity of real organisms. In order to assess the potential role and implications of field theories in development, it is first necessary to show that this type of mechanism is capable of generating the kind of order found in biological morphogenesis.
chunks.section: Many attempts to model specific developmental processes exist
chunks.chunk_summary: Existing developmental models utilize various mathematical approaches, but their ability to fully capture biological complexity remains an open question.

chunks.text: It is also interesting to examine some of the features of the morphogenetic process which is controlled in this way. To these ends, a computer model was developed. This model turned out to be remarkably similar to algorithms used to generate fractal images, which have been extensively used to model complete biological shapes (e.g. Prusinkiewicz and Lindenmeyer, 1990). The original model described in this paper attempts a wider view of the control processes of development, by modeling cell decisions controlled by field-specified positional information.
chunks.section: Many attempts to model specific developmental processes exist
chunks.chunk_summary: A computer model, similar to fractal image generation algorithms, was developed to study the control processes of development by modeling cell decisions based on positional information.

chunks.text: The model has a strong bottom-up component in that it is based on a process which is known to be crucial in biomorphogenesis - determination of cell fates via gene interactions. It is top-down in that it is not a simulation of any specific actual organism, but of a type of process - positional information interpretation based on genetic interactions. It is not being claimed that the specific formulas (used below) describe any existent organism; rather, it is a computer implementation of a possible morphogenetic control process. Thus, the strength of the model is not based on the fact that the images produced may look like biological forms, but lies in the fact that the model can be used to study the higher-order properties of field-directed gene interactions in morphogenesis.
chunks.section: Many attempts to model specific developmental processes exist
chunks.chunk_summary: The model combines bottom-up (gene interactions) and top-down (positional information) approaches to study the general properties of field-directed morphogenesis, rather than simulating specific organisms.

chunks.text: It makes several concrete predictions, and explains several key phenomena. When quantitative information on morphogenetic gene interactions becomes available, this can be used within the context of the model described herein to make concrete predictions about specific organisms.
chunks.section: Many attempts to model specific developmental processes exist
chunks.chunk_summary: The model generates predictions about morphogenetic phenomena and can be used with future quantitative data to make predictions about specific organisms.

chunks.text: The Julia set model is mentioned on page 87.  Due to the extremely limited information provided, no further details about the model's application or relevance to the overall research can be extracted.
chunks.section: [PAGE 87] The Julia set model
chunks.chunk_summary: The section mentions the Julia set model on page 87, but provides no further details.

chunks.text: Interpretation
chunks.section: Interpretation
chunks.chunk_summary: This section is titled 'Interpretation'.

chunks.text: Morphogenesis is seen to be a three-stage process: (i) a positional information field is specified (by factors in the external environment, by the mother's organism, or by components within the embryo itself); (ii) cells go through a complex set of genetic interactions and phenotypic effects, and then achieve some final genetic state based on their positions within this field; and (iii) this genetic state determines the behavior of the cell (migration, proliferation, apoptosis, adhesion, etc.).
chunks.section: Morphogenesis is seen to be a three
chunks.chunk_summary: Morphogenesis is a three-stage process involving positional information, genetic interactions leading to a final genetic state, and cell behavior determined by this state.

chunks.text: The mechanical interactions of the cells finally determine the overall morphology of the organism.
chunks.section: Morphogenesis is seen to be a three
chunks.chunk_summary: Mechanical interactions between cells ultimately determine the organism's morphology.

chunks.text: The current model consists of a computer algorithm which simulates cell behavior within a field. Each cell finds itself within some unique position in a two-dimensional field; a mathematical function (shown to be isomorphic to a modified Julia set, after Pickover, 1990) then describes the behavior of the cell at that position. Of course it is not being suggested that there is a mechanism within the cell that computes this function in the sense of formal computation; rather, the function is descriptive of the cell's behavior (much as Newton's laws describe the motion of the moon, without any need for the moon formally to compute the functions).
chunks.section: The current model consists of a computer algorithm which simulates cell behavior within a field
chunks.chunk_summary: A computational model using a mathematical function, isomorphic to a modified Julia set, describes cell behavior based on position within a 2D field, not implying cells perform formal computation.

chunks.text: This model is similar to Thompson's (1961) model since applying the deformations to the axes is equivalent to applying a deformation to the coordinate points making up the image. Thus, Thompson's model also represents a positional-field interpretation model, but is different from the model presented in this paper because his model applies a deformation to an existing form, while the model described here generates the morphology *de novo*.
chunks.section: The current model consists of a computer algorithm which simulates cell behavior within a field
chunks.chunk_summary: While similar to Thompson's (1961) positional-field model in its use of deformations, the current model differs by generating morphology de novo rather than deforming existing forms.

chunks.text: Specifically, the simulation models cell fate determination through a complex cycle of gene product interactions, similar to Kauffman's 1969 model.  Cell state is represented by concentrations of gene products (P₁, P₂, ...), which interact and regulate each other's expression over time.  These interactions are represented by a function *F()*, which transforms the cell state from <P₁, P₂, ... > to <P₁', P₂',...> over discrete time steps.
chunks.section: Specifically
chunks.chunk_summary: The simulation models cell fate decisions based on gene product interactions and their changes over time, represented by a state transition function.

chunks.text: The simulation iteratively applies the function *F()* to an initial totipotent cell state until a stable point is reached, representing the cell's differentiation path. This iterative process models the complex gene interactions that lead to a stable differentiated state.  Two possible stable points exist: either specific gene products exceed a threshold, activating a differentiation program, or no threshold is reached, resulting in a stem cell-like state that remains undifferentiated.
chunks.section: Specifically
chunks.chunk_summary: The simulation iteratively applies a function to model gene interactions until a stable differentiated or stem cell-like state is reached.

chunks.text: In this model, only two gene products are considered, *X* and *Y*. Though in reality a larger set of genes is clearly responsible for the morphogenesis of features in organisms, it is one of the important results of this study that two genes are sufficient to produce a very rich set of morphologies with properties similar to those of real morphogenetic processes. Each cell is at a certain position *x,y* within the field (two-dimensional, as a simplification). This position is interpreted (perhaps by a mechanism similar to that of *Hox* genes, as in Tabin, 1991) to arrive at a specific initial concentration of two gene products, <*X,Y*>. Then, a function is applied (simulating gene regulation) which alters *X* and *Y* in an interdependent manner (e.g. it might map *X, Y* to *X* , *c* . *Y* , modeling a linear inhibition of expression of *X* by the product of *Y*).
chunks.section: In this model
chunks.chunk_summary: A simplified two-gene model demonstrates that complex morphologies can arise from interdependent gene regulation based on cell position.

chunks.text: The function is taken to be a map in complex numbers (thus an *N*-dimensional algebra can be defined for modeling the interactions of *N* genes), so that (*X, Y*) is represented as *X* + *Y*i, and is applied for a number of iterations. At the end, either the magnitude of *X* or the magnitude of *Y* has reached a certain threshold value, or neither has. Whether the limit has been reached, and if so, how quickly, determines the 'type' of the cell. This algorithm is extremely similar to one used in generating various fractal images, and is isomorphic to Julia set computation.
chunks.section: In this model
chunks.chunk_summary: The iterative application of a complex number function, similar to Julia set computation, determines cell type based on the magnitude of gene product concentrations.

chunks.text: Fractals, exhibiting self-similarity across scales, are found in various biological structures.  This brief mention of fractals in biology suggests their relevance to the broader themes of the paper, likely relating to pattern formation and complex organization in biological systems.
chunks.section: [PAGE 88] Fractals in biology
chunks.chunk_summary: Fractals, characterized by self-similarity, appear in biological structures, suggesting their role in pattern formation and complex organization.

chunks.text: Julia sets are generated by a fractal algorithm, and are closely related to Mandelbrot sets. While the mathematics behind these objects is fairly well researched, their higher-order (morphological) characteristics are relatively poorly understood. Some considerations of the mathematical properties of complex iterations are found in Beardon (1990, 1991). This is a new (the first articles began to appear around 1968) and very active topic in mathematics.
chunks.section: Julia sets are generated by a fractal algorithm
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk introduces Julia sets, their relation to Mandelbrot sets, and the current state of research on their morphological properties.

chunks.text: Fractals' main features are widely differing behaviors for close initial points (chaos, due to their recursiveness which magnifies small differences), their production of images that are self-similar in regions, and the incredible richness of structures, which is produced by very short formulas (Peitgen and Saupe, 1988). Note that fractals' chaotic behavior provides a possible answer to the question (Lewis et al., 1977) of how a smooth (continuous) field can give rise to discrete cell states (the problem of sharp thresholds): the potential for two very close complex field values to have widely different fates under iterative transformations is a hallmark of fractal (chaotic) algorithms.
chunks.section: Julia sets are generated by a fractal algorithm
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk describes the key features of fractals, including chaos, self-similarity, and their potential role in generating discrete cell states from continuous fields.

chunks.text: Thus, after a time of genetic interactions, two close cell states <*X, Y*> and <*X', Y*> can diverge to become widely differing cell types, providing sharp differentiation boundaries within a continuous field.
chunks.section: Julia sets are generated by a fractal algorithm
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk explains how fractal algorithms, through their chaotic behavior, can contribute to cell differentiation and the establishment of sharp boundaries between cell types within a continuous field.

chunks.text: Fractal algorithms are highly 'epigenetic', and the generativeness is uni-directional. That is, given a fractal formula it is very easy to produce the complex morphology it codes for (as a complex biological organism is formed as a result of chemical reactions driven by the information content of DNA); however, given a complete morphology, it is exceedingly difficult to find a short formula that codes for it (as would be very difficult, given the morphology of an organism, to determine the content of the DNA which would produce that organism).
chunks.section: Fractal algorithms are highly
chunks.chunk_summary: Fractal algorithms exhibit unidirectional generativeness, making it easy to generate complex morphology from a formula but difficult to derive the formula from the morphology, analogous to the relationship between DNA and organismal form.

chunks.text: The same sort of reason that may explain why there is no inheritance of acquired characteristics (that the epigenetic character of development makes it nearly impossible to translate directly some characteristic of an organism back into its DNA) makes it very difficult to find a fractal formula coding for some given morphology.
chunks.section: Fractal algorithms are highly
chunks.chunk_summary: The difficulty of translating organismal characteristics back into DNA, similar to the challenge of deriving fractal formulas from morphology, may explain the lack of inheritance of acquired characteristics.

chunks.text: The fact that Julia sets map positions in a plane to discrete scalar values by iterating interdependent changes of several independent values makes them a natural candidate for a positional information model of pattern formation due to differential gene activation. Pietronero and Tosatti (1986) and Feder and Aharony (1990) present overviews of the importance of fractals in the study of physical processes. Fractal and chaotic algorithms form the basis for many physical processes important in development, such as diffusion-limited aggregation (Witten and Sander, 1981; Witten and Cates, 1986), viscous fingering (Sander, 1987) and percolation (Oxaal et al., 1987). A great sourcebook for this information is the classic Mandelbrot (1982).
chunks.section: The fact that Julia sets map positions in a plane to discrete scalar values by iterating interdependent changes of several independent values makes them a natural candidate for a positional information model of pattern formation due to differential gene activation
chunks.chunk_summary: Fractal and chaotic algorithms, including Julia sets, are relevant to developmental processes like diffusion-limited aggregation, viscous fingering, and percolation, and may serve as models for positional information and pattern formation.

chunks.text: These algorithms have been used in modeling and analyzing biophysical systems [e.g. ion channel activity (Liebovitch and Töth, 1990), neural activity (Ishibashi et al., 1988) and dielectric response in biological tissues (Dissado, 1990)], various biological phenomena [e.g. periodontal disease (Landini, 1991), metabolism (Sernetz et al., 1985; and for many more examples, West, 1991)], evolution (Green, 1991) and the development of different components of embryos, such as nerves, blood vessels and mosaic organs (see, for example, Meakin, 1986; Mainster, 1990; Iannaccone, 1990; Burlando et al., 1991; Kiani and Hudetz, 1991; Smith et al., 1991; Vaidya et al., 1991).
chunks.section: The fact that Julia sets map positions in a plane to discrete scalar values by iterating interdependent changes of several independent values makes them a natural candidate for a positional information model of pattern formation due to differential gene activation
chunks.chunk_summary: Fractal and chaotic algorithms have been applied to model diverse biological phenomena, including biophysical systems, diseases, metabolism, evolution, and embryonic development.

chunks.text: Complex systems, especially biological organisms, are characterized by numerous interconnected attributes with non-obvious interaction rules, non-linearity, and seemingly stochastic dynamics, as described by Goel and Thompson (1988). These characteristics are effectively represented by Julia set behavior.
chunks.section: Complex systems
chunks.chunk_summary: Biological organisms, as complex systems, exhibit interconnected attributes, non-linearity, and stochastic dynamics, effectively captured by Julia set behavior.

chunks.text: The hypothesis that the differentiation pathway for a cell is determined by iterative chaotic processes has an interesting consequence, mirroring a similar result in the theory of dynamical systems. While for any given cell the final outcome (i.e. which differentiation fate is taken) is physically predetermined, in certain (though not all) cases it may be impossible to know what that outcome will be, even with good data about the initial gene product concentrations, since the gene interactions are iterative and thus magnify minute differences in initial conditions. Two widely divergent differentiation pathways may thus result from very close (and perhaps indistinguishable within some technique's precision) gene activity levels.
chunks.section: The hypothesis that the differentiation pathway for a cell is determined by iterative chaotic processes has an interesting consequence
chunks.chunk_summary: While cell differentiation outcomes are predetermined by chaotic, iterative gene interactions, predicting the specific fate can be impossible due to the magnification of minute initial differences in gene product concentrations.

chunks.text: The formal definition of the Julia set model algorithm is presented on page 89.
chunks.section: [PAGE 89] The formal definition of the Julia set model algorithm
chunks.chunk_summary: This section introduces the formal definition of the Julia set model algorithm.

chunks.text: The basic algorithm maps cell behavior onto a rectangular field of cells. For each position in the field, a formula is applied, and the resulting cell behavior (e.g., differentiation) is plotted at that position with a specific color. The color mapping for different cell 'types' is arbitrary.
chunks.section: The basic algorithm is as follows
chunks.chunk_summary: The algorithm plots cell behavior on a rectangular grid based on a formula, using color to represent different cell types.

chunks.text: The pseudocode representation of the algorithm iterates through each position (X, Y) within the field, from minimum to maximum values for both X and Y.  For each position, it plots a point at (X, Y) with a color T, which is determined by a function of X, Y, and potentially other parameters (P).
chunks.section: The basic algorithm is as follows
chunks.chunk_summary: The pseudocode iterates through the field, plotting points with colors determined by their position and other parameters.

chunks.text: Thus, the function Φ() maps each position (*X, Y*) and a constant *v* to a type *T*. *X* and *Y* are varied within some range of values, and there is a finite and discrete number of types *T*. This corresponds to the biological case of a continuous population of primitive (undifferentiated), non-motile cells, within a two-dimensional positional information field, which differentiate as a function of their position in the field.
chunks.section: Thus
chunks.chunk_summary: A mathematical function Φ() models cell differentiation based on position within a two-dimensional field, representing how cells in a continuous population differentiate according to their spatial location.

chunks.text: Thus, formally a given morphology is a quintuple M = <λ, Φ, ν, R, T>, where λ is the field limitation - the domain of the field values seen by the subunits (upper and lower bounds on X and Y values for the points examined). In terms of biological development, this expresses the boundaries on the field values that cells experience. Φ is the function - a mathematical function describing the input-output relation between the cell's position and its resulting type (describing the cell's mechanism for interaction with the field, some type of receptor, or membrane mechanism, which is determined by the cell's DNA). This function performs the iteration of the initial X, Y values through some complex formula.
chunks.section: Thus
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk introduces a mathematical model of morphology as a quintuple, defining the field limitation (λ) and the function (Φ) relating cell position to type.

chunks.text: ν, the constant used in the function, represents some existing identical information all of the cells have when they begin morphogenesis. R is the resolution, which determines how many points in the interval from Xmin to Xmax and Ymin to Ymax are sampled. In terms of biological systems, this parameter specifies how much of the morphology is a result of field-cell interactions, and how much is to be provided by purely local interactions which fill in the spaces between the field-specified points. T is the set of possible cell behaviors (differentiation pathways).
chunks.section: Thus
chunks.chunk_summary: This chunk defines the remaining parameters of the morphology model: the constant (ν), resolution (R), and the set of possible cell behaviors (T).

chunks.text: Computer implementation of the described bioelectric model allows for simulation and prediction of morphogenetic outcomes. While the provided section content is extremely limited, it implies the use of computational tools to translate biological mechanisms into a workable model. This approach enables researchers to explore the dynamics of bioelectric signaling and its influence on tissue-level patterns.  Further details on the specific implementation are not provided in this brief section.
chunks.section: [PAGE 89] Computer implementation
chunks.chunk_summary: This section briefly mentions the use of computer implementation for simulating a bioelectric model and predicting morphogenetic outcomes.

chunks.text: In a computer program, the field is implemented as the R² space - a plane where each point corresponds to a complex number a + bi. Thus, for each point there is an *X* and *Y* value (corresponding to the concentrations of two different and orthogonally diffusing chemicals, in a morphogen field, for example, or the adhesiveness of two separate surfaces, in a tactile field). The function that is applied to the locations in the field is, in this model, a modified Julia set calculation.
chunks.section: In a computer program
chunks.chunk_summary: This model uses a 2D plane (R² space) where each point represents a complex number, corresponding to properties like chemical concentrations or surface adhesiveness, and applies a modified Julia set calculation to these points.

chunks.text: [which differ from true Julia sets in that a point is plotted if and only if | real(z) | < limit or | imaginary(z) | < limit]. That is, for each given point (complex number) *Z*, its value is recursively iterated through a formula such as z = z² + ν, and the original point *Z* is plotted in a color which is related to how many iterations occurred before z exceeded some limit value. Some formal theory regarding these functions can be found in Beardon (1991).
chunks.section: In a computer program
chunks.chunk_summary: Modified Julia set calculations are used, where points are plotted based on the number of iterations it takes for their value to exceed a limit, visualized through color coding, with theoretical background found in Beardon (1991).

chunks.text: Note that the images thus produced are those of pre-pattern - they are analogous to an *in situ* mRNA hybridization because they are showing final genetic states of cells, not what the organism actually looks like. The real morphology of an organism is derived from this pre-pattern by cell movements, mechanical deformations, apoptosis, etc., which are governed by the genetic states of the cells.
chunks.section: Note that the images thus produced are those of pre
chunks.chunk_summary: Visualizations represent pre-patterns of gene expression, analogous to *in situ* hybridization, and not the final morphology, which arises from cell behaviors governed by these genetic states.

chunks.text: This limit value is a constraint on which points appear in the final image, and its biological interpretation is thus as a measure of the importance of the positional information. A high limit value would allow relatively many points to be placed, indicating that cells' fates are heavily influenced by the positional information.
chunks.section: This limit value is a constraint on which points appear in the final image
chunks.chunk_summary: The limit value determines the influence of positional information on cell fate during image generation.

chunks.text: A low limit value would allow relatively few points
chunks.section: This limit value is a constraint on which points appear in the final image
chunks.chunk_summary: A low limit value restricts the impact of positional information on cell fate.

chunks.text: Julia set models can be applied to field-driven development, suggesting that not all cells receive fate instructions directly from the global positional field.  Instead, some key cells interpret the field and then influence their neighbors through local interactions, leading to a pattern where only certain cells directly rely on the field for their fate.
chunks.section: [PAGE 91] Julia set model of field-driven development
chunks.chunk_summary: Julia set models suggest that in field-driven development, some key cells interpret the positional field and influence neighboring cell fates through local interactions.

chunks.text: Note that the floating-point routines used in any computer's math library have a limit on their accuracy. This provides a natural limit to the differences in positional information that the cells will be able to detect, and corresponds to the limits in sensitivity of real cells to field values which differ by very small values.
chunks.section: Note that the floating
chunks.chunk_summary: The inherent limitations of computer floating-point calculations impose constraints on the precision of positional information detectable by cells, mirroring the limited sensitivity of real cells to minute field value differences.

chunks.text: It is important to realize that the formula in z is not identical with the function Φ() mentioned above. The function Φ() includes the formula, iteration and cutoff decision, and is used only once for each point; it maps a given (*x,y*) pair to a given type (color). The definition of Φ() subsumes the iteration of the complex function, and the intermediate values of the real and imaginary components of z represent the concentrations of various gene products, as explained above.
chunks.section: It is important to realize that the formula in z is not identical with the function
chunks.chunk_summary: The function Φ() encompasses the formula, iteration, cutoff decision, and maps a given (x,y) pair to a type/color, with intermediate values of z representing gene product concentrations.

chunks.text: The actual formulas used to produce the figures are shown in Table I. Note that on different computers certain parts of the pictures may look somewhat different than they do in the illustrations below. This is due to the accumulation of differences in machines' floating-point calculation errors (which are magnified due to the iterations of the formulas).
chunks.section: The actual formulas used to produce the figures are shown in Table I
chunks.chunk_summary: Formulas used for generating figures are presented in Table I, with a note about potential visual variations due to computational differences across machines.

chunks.text: Biologically relevant properties of morphologies produced by this computational model are examined. This brief section introduces the concept of assessing the biological realism of the generated shapes, implying a subsequent deeper analysis in the paper.  The focus is on evaluating whether the model's output aligns with observed biological structures and their functional characteristics.
chunks.section: [PAGE 91] Biologically relevant properties of morphologies produced by this model
chunks.chunk_summary: This section introduces the concept of evaluating the biological relevance of morphologies generated by a computational model.

chunks.text: The figures show the variety of gene expression patterns that can be produced by only two gene products and a smooth linear Cartesian coordinate field. It is clear that this is sufficient to produce extremely rich patterns, which can be even further elaborated by cell movements and rearrangements to produce an embryo's final morphology.
chunks.section: The figures show the variety of gene expression patterns that can be produced by only two gene products and a smooth linear Cartesian coordinate field
chunks.chunk_summary: Two gene products and a coordinate field can generate diverse gene expression patterns, further refined by cell movements to shape embryonic morphology.

chunks.text: Of course it is not being suggested that all of the features observed in the figures are actually used in organisms' morphologies; rather these results show that the kinds of patterns found in biological systems can be plausibly produced by such a model.
chunks.section: The figures show the variety of gene expression patterns that can be produced by only two gene products and a smooth linear Cartesian coordinate field
chunks.chunk_summary: While not all features in the figures are necessarily used in organisms, the model demonstrates the plausibility of generating biological patterns.

chunks.text: 1. General notes on static shapes and how they resemble real organisms' morphologies
chunks.section: 1. General notes on static shapes and how they resemble real organisms' morphologies
chunks.chunk_summary: This section introduces the concept of comparing static shapes to the morphologies of real organisms.

chunks.text: Several general traits of these figures (see, for example, Figures 3-18) are similar to those of real organisms. Note how colors never merge - borders are well-defined; differentiation proceeds in layers, with distinct boundaries. There are clear borders between separate structures; there are many instances of objects possessing a definite inside and outside. There are almost no straight lines; curves predominate.
chunks.section: Several general traits of these figures
chunks.chunk_summary: The generated figures exhibit distinct boundaries, layered differentiation, and predominantly curved lines, mirroring characteristics of real organisms.

chunks.text: As in real biological organisms, the morphology is an epigenetic phenomenon of the formula expressing the genetic interactions - it is very difficult to predict the large-scale morphological properties of the organism from the formula (genome).
chunks.section: Several general traits of these figures
chunks.chunk_summary: Morphology is an epigenetic outcome of genetic interactions, making it challenging to predict large-scale morphology solely from the genome.

chunks.text: Repeated magnification reveals ever more intricate detail, but every function described in this paper possesses a top-most view - a scale beyond which nothing interesting happens. This indicates that for every organism, there are limits on which field values are valid (as perceived by the cells); the positional information field has definite edges.
chunks.section: Repeated magnification reveals ever more intricate detail
chunks.chunk_summary: Biological functions have a top-most scale, indicating limits on perceivable field values and definite edges for positional information fields.

chunks.text: As in real organisms, there are recurrent spatial motifs - most of the images build on the same types of morphologies over and over again. Repeated segments are used in many images (see for example Figures 3, 24 and 57). Most figures show clear examples of structural hierarchies (a mathematical analysis of structural hierarchies in biological systems appears in Totafurno et al., 1980).
chunks.section: Repeated magnification reveals ever more intricate detail
chunks.chunk_summary: The images exhibit recurrent spatial motifs and structural hierarchies, similar to real organisms.

chunks.text: The symmetry properties of these functions are also reminiscent of life. Many images are truly symmetrical along one axis (as in Figures 5, 7 and 8); some are radially symmetrical (such as Figure 20). Some are regular, but not symmetrical along any axis (such as Figures 15 and 23).
chunks.section: The symmetry properties of these functions are also reminiscent of life
chunks.chunk_summary: Biological structures exhibit various types of symmetry, including axial, radial, and asymmetry.

chunks.text: And others, such as Figure 27, seem to be bilaterally symmetrical, but close inspection reveals differences that break the symmetry (look closely at the distribution of the solid black sectors in Figure 27, and at the outgrowth to the right of Figure 59, reminiscent of the kinds of asymmetries found in crabs and lobsters); this resembles the morphology of many organisms that are bilaterally symmetrical, except for various features (such as the heart and liver in the human).
chunks.section: The symmetry properties of these functions are also reminiscent of life
chunks.chunk_summary: While some structures appear bilaterally symmetrical, closer examination reveals broken symmetry, similar to organ asymmetry in organisms like humans, crabs, and lobsters.

chunks.text: Many parts of the images are self-similar (see Figures 4 and 20), though are not exactly repeated units. There is usually some top-level shape, within which there are self-similar structures. Biological forms display many examples of self-similarity (for examples see West and Goldberger, 1987; Mandelbrot, 1982; Nelson and Goldberger, 1990; Guyon and Stanley, 1991; West, 1991).
chunks.section: Many parts of the images are self
chunks.chunk_summary: Biological images exhibit self-similarity across different scales, suggesting a hierarchical organization.

chunks.text: This self-similarity implies that the algorithm itself, with a given formula, dictates a specific shape, and this shape is basically the same in many regions of the field, at different resolutions. This means that (i) field values are relative, not absolute, and experiments with field-directed developmental systems can be done to test this; and (ii) parts of the field contain information for the whole organism.
chunks.section: Many parts of the images are self
chunks.chunk_summary: The self-similarity observed suggests that morphogenetic fields, with relative values, guide development and that local regions contain information about the whole organism.

chunks.text: This 'holographic' property of the model is interesting in light of the ability of many kinds of embryos (at certain stages) to regenerate from pieces, and recover the whole organism when pieces are removed. As with real embryos, not every region contains the crucial information, and only some regions can be 'magnified' into the proper morphology. Real embryos also possess this 'relativity' of positional information (e.g. in certain cases in early *Drosophila* axis formation, it is the relative concentrations of two morphogens which matter, not their absolute concentrations).
chunks.section: This
chunks.chunk_summary: Embryonic regeneration exhibits a 'holographic' property where only certain regions contain the information necessary for complete organismal recovery, highlighting the relativity of positional information during development.

chunks.text: During morphogenesis there is a 'matching of proportionate spatial structures to the size of the field in which the pattern is formed. It appears as if a size-sensing mechanism exists which controls and adapts the detailed structures in accordance with the variable field size, so that their relative extent remains invariant' (Papageorgiou and Venieratos, 1983). This is seen in the experiments on *Xenopus* (Cooke, 1973c, 1979, 1981), hydra (Bode and Bode, 1980) and a unicellular ciliate (Bakowska and Jerka-Dziadosz, 1980).
chunks.section: This
chunks.chunk_summary: A size-sensing mechanism during morphogenesis ensures that spatial structures are proportionally matched to the field size, maintaining relative proportions across different scales, as evidenced by experiments in various organisms.

chunks.text: Might this property be supported by a morphogenetic field? In general, patterns generated by diffusion reactions are very sensitive to changes of scale. However, a variation on Turing's early model (Othmer and Pate, 1980) of spatial formation based on morphogen reaction-diffusion systems also exhibits scale invariance. A theoretical basis for morphogen gradient fields that exhibit scale invariance is given in Papageorgiou and Venieratos (1983).
chunks.section: [PAGE 92] M.Levin
chunks.chunk_summary: This section explores the concept of morphogenetic fields and their potential role in supporting scale-invariant pattern formation through reaction-diffusion systems, referencing Turing's model and subsequent variations.

chunks.text: In general, these images demonstrate that just two interacting genes can generate complex morphologies from a smooth and continuous positional information field. This finding is significant because it offers a plausible and biochemically feasible explanation for how organismic complexity can emerge from two simple orthogonal vectors.
chunks.section: In general
chunks.chunk_summary: Two interacting genes are sufficient to create complex morphologies from a simple positional information field.

chunks.text: Figure 34 shows a low-structure morphology characterized by simple circular layers of aggregated (mixed-color) tissue, produced by a simple formula. The image exhibits radial symmetry, with the exception of a small horizontal line on the right.
chunks.section: Figure
chunks.chunk_summary: Figure 34 depicts a simple, circular morphology generated by a basic formula.

chunks.text: Figure 35 displays the same formula as Figure 34, with an added component, resulting in a slightly more complex morphology. While modifications to the circular membrane of Figure 34 are present, the overall structure remains simpler than other figures.
chunks.section: Figure
chunks.chunk_summary: Figure 35 builds upon the formula of Figure 34, introducing increased complexity while maintaining relative simplicity.

chunks.text: Figures 36 and 37 show two morphologies which correspond to gene interactions that fail to produce coherent morphologies. Note the failure of layers to join in many places, and the confused disordered arrangement of internal detail (especially apparent in Figure 37).
chunks.section: Figures
chunks.chunk_summary: Figures 36 and 37 illustrate incoherent morphologies resulting from failed gene interactions, characterized by unconnected layers and disordered internal details.

chunks.text: Another interesting example is seen in Figure 41 (this is just a magnification of the area overlaid by the dashed rectangle in Figure 1): note the complex behavior that occurs where two separate structures overlap. This should be studied further in light of the competing field influence found in *Xenopus* (Cooke, 1972a-c, 1973a,b).
chunks.section: Figures
chunks.chunk_summary: Figure 41 highlights complex behavior at the overlap of two structures, suggesting further study in the context of competing field influences observed in Xenopus.

chunks.text: [PAGE 92] 2. Parametrization: how forms change in response to parameter changes
chunks.section: Figures
chunks.chunk_summary: The section introduces the concept of parametrization, exploring how morphological forms change in response to varying parameters.

chunks.text: An important set of questions can be answered by this model through parametrization studies. The role of a given component (gene interaction rule) in producing the morphology can be studied by tracking the changes in the image as its value is slowly changed. Several things can be studied in this way: constants in the formula itself, the limit used in the cutoff point, the intercellular constant (ν), etc.
chunks.section: An important set of questions can be answered by this model through parametrization studies
chunks.chunk_summary: Parametrization studies, involving adjusting components like gene interaction rules and intercellular constants, can reveal their impact on morphology by tracking image changes.

chunks.text: The parametrization studies described below show that smoothly changing gene co-regulation functions from R² to R²
chunks.section: An important set of questions can be answered by this model through parametrization studies
chunks.chunk_summary: Parametrization studies demonstrate the impact of smoothly changing gene co-regulation functions within a defined mathematical space (R² to R²).
